# import Symbolic Python (SymPy)

from sympy import init_printing # use LaTeX style typesetting of output
init_printing() # turn on typesetting

children.value:
from sympy import Matrix, symbols

# Define symbolic variables
x, y, z = symbols('x y z')
A, B, C, D, E, F = symbols('A B C D E F')

To put a matrix into reduced row echelon form, use rref. The method rref returns a tuple of two elements. The first is the reduced row echelon form, and the second is a tuple of indices of the pivot columns.
We’ll talk about what you do with this next section
the answers are: x = 5, y = -1, and z = 2.
Example: Felder and Felder Section 7.4 Problem 7.99

children.value: We have 4 reactions as constraints on 6 constitutents, so we need to choose at least 2 as constants and allow the remaining concentrations to be variables for which we want to solve.
In this problem, we are directed to choose A and B as our constants — known values — so we want to express everything else in terms of A and B. The resulting equations are

children.html: (2AA2B2B)=(−32042012−5406−7046)(CDEF)\begin{pmatrix} 2A \\ A \\ 2B \\ 2B \\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -3 & 2 & 0 & 4 \\ 2 & 0 & 1 & 2 \\ -5 & 4 & 0 & 6 \\ -7 & 0 & 4 & 6 \\ \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} C \\ D \\ E \\ F \\ \end{pmatrix}⎝⎛​2AA2B2B​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​−32−5−7​2040​0104​4266​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​CDEF​⎠⎞​
(−32042A2012A−54062B−70462B)\begin{pmatrix} -3 & 2 & 0 & 4 & 2A \\ 2 & 0 & 1 & 2 & A \\ -5 & 4 & 0 & 6 & 2B \\ -7 & 0 & 4 & 6 & 2B \\ \end{pmatrix}⎝⎛​−32−5−7​2040​0104​4266​2AA2B2B​⎠⎞​

children.value:
# let Sympy know what our variables are 
A, B, C, D, E, F = symbols('A B C D E F')

text/latex.content: $\displaystyle \left[\begin{matrix}1 & 0 & 0 & -2 & - 4 A + 2 B\\0 & 1 & 0 & -1 & - 5 A + 3 B\\0 & 0 & 1 & -2 & - 7 A + 4 B\\0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0\end{matrix}\right]$

children.value: What do our results say? The good news is the four equations are linearly dependent. The bad news is that there are only 3 pivot points —  the fourth row returns zeros — so this  says our matrix is of rank ‘3’.
In non-matrix speak,  there are only 3 independent reactions among the 4 listed, so we can’t solve uniquely for A and B.
To solve this problem completely, we would need to specify the value of one more constituent. To do this, one of our 4 variables must become a constant, like A and B.
let’s try again with 3 constants (input variables): methane (A), ethane (B), and oxygen (C).

children.html: (2A+3CA+2C2B+5C2B+7C)=(204012406046)(DEF)\begin{pmatrix} 2A + 3C \\ A + 2C \\ 2B +5C \\ 2B + 7C \\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 4 & 0 & 6 \\ 0 & 4 & 6 \\ \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} D \\ E \\ F \\ \end{pmatrix}⎝⎛​2A+3CA+2C2B+5C2B+7C​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​2040​0104​4266​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​DEF​⎠⎞​

(−32042A+3C2012A+2C−54062B+5C−70462B+7C)\begin{pmatrix} -3 & 2 & 0 & 4 & 2A +3C \\ 2 & 0 & 1 & 2 & A +2C\\ -5 & 4 & 0 & 6 & 2B +5C\\ -7 & 0 & 4 & 6 & 2B +7C\\ \end{pmatrix}⎝⎛​−32−5−7​2040​0104​4266​2A+3CA+2C2B+5C2B+7C​⎠⎞​

text/latex.content: $\displaystyle \left[\begin{matrix}2 & 0 & 4 & 2 A + 3 C\\0 & 1 & 2 & A + 2 C\\4 & 0 & 6 & 2 B + 5 C\\0 & 4 & 6 & 2 B + 7 C\end{matrix}\right]$

$\displaystyle \left( \left[\begin{matrix}1 & 0 & 0 & - 3 A + 2 B + \frac{C}{2}\\0 & 1 & 0 & - 3 A + 2 B + C\\0 & 0 & 1 & 2 A - B + \frac{C}{2}\\0 & 0 & 0 & 0\end{matrix}\right], \  \left( 0, \  1, \  2\right)\right)$

children.value: It means that if we know the starting values of methane(A), ethane(B), and oxygen(C), then we can solve for the amounts of each of resulting chemicals:

children.html: D=−3A+2B+(1/2)C D = -3A + 2B + (1/2)CD=−3A+2B+(1/2)C
E=−3A+2B+C E = -3A + 2B + CE=−3A+2B+C
F=2A−B+(1/2)C F = 2A - B + (1/2)CF=2A−B+(1/2)C

6 unknowns - A B C D E F
3 equations

text/latex.content: $\displaystyle \left[\begin{matrix}1 & -1 & 1 & - A\\0 & 0 & 1 & - A + B - C\\1 & -1 & 0 & - B + C\end{matrix}\right]$

children.value: The last row is an all-zero row, thus this is in a RREF form. This system is linearly dependent, and as there are 2 pivot points, this matrix is of rank ‘2’. We only need two constants.
Above results show that this system is linearly dependent, having infinite solutions.
When two of the final concentrations are measured, the rest can be determined.

Above shows that this system is linearly dependent, having infinite solutions. As there are 4 pivot points, this matrix is of rank ‘4’. We need to measure
of the final concentrations, then we can calculate the remaining two concentrations.
